subsection.name: Description
subsection.div: Checks the number of methods declared in each type declaration by access modifier or total count.
subsection.p: This check can be configured to flag classes that define too many methods to prevent the class from getting too complex. Counting can be customized to prevent too many total methods in a type definition (maxTotal), or to prevent too many methods of a specific access modifier (private, package, protected or public). Each count is completely separated to customize how many methods of each you want to allow. For example, specifying a maxTotal of 10, still means you can prevent more than 0 maxPackage methods. A violation won't appear for 8 public methods, but one will appear if there is also 3 private methods or any package-private methods.
Methods defined in anonymous classes are not counted towards any totals. Counts only go towards the main type declaration parent, and are kept separate from it's children's inner types.

To configure the check to allow no more than 2 public methods per type declaration, and 6 methods in total:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="TreeWalker"> <module name="MethodCount"> <property name="maxPublic" value="2"/> <property name="maxTotal" value="6"/> </module> </module> </module>

subsection.p: To configure the check to use separate maximums for private, package-private, and protected methods:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="TreeWalker"> <module name="MethodCount"> <property name="maxPrivate" value="1"/> <property name="maxPackage" value="2"/> <property name="maxProtected" value="2"/> </module> </module> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.
